title: Jeremiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 5 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 5.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah instructed to do in the streets of Jerusalem according to Jeremiah 5:1?
options: Run to and fro and seek a man who executes judgment and seeks the truth
questions.correctAnswer: Run to and fro and seek a man who executes judgment and seeks the truth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:1 instructs to run through the streets of Jerusalem to find a man who executes judgment and seeks the truth.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:2, what do people do even though they say 'The LORD liveth'?
questions.correctAnswer: They swear falsely
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:2 states that even though people say 'The LORD liveth,' they swear falsely.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 5:6, which animals are mentioned as instruments of judgment against the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Lion, wolf, and leopard
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:6 describes a lion, a wolf, and a leopard as agents that will slay and spoil the people.

questions.question: What have the children done according to Jeremiah 5:7?
options: Forsaken God and sworn by gods that are not gods
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaken God and sworn by gods that are not gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:7 says the children have forsaken the LORD and sworn by gods that are not gods.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:9, what does the LORD say He will do to the nation?
options: His soul will be avenged on such a nation
He will give them peace forever
He will protect them from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: His soul will be avenged on such a nation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:9 states that the LORD's soul will be avenged on such a nation because of their actions.

questions.question: What does God command in Jeremiah 5:10 regarding the walls?
options: Destroy but do not make a full end; take away the battlements
Build new walls and strengthen the gates
Paint the walls with bright colors
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy but do not make a full end; take away the battlements
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:10 commands to destroy the walls but not to make a full end and to take away the battlements because they are not the LORD's.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:12, what have the people said about the LORD?
options: It is not he; neither shall evil come upon us
He is our protector and king
He will bless us with harvest
questions.correctAnswer: It is not he; neither shall evil come upon us
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:12 says that the people have lied about the LORD, claiming it is not He and no evil will come upon them.

questions.question: What will happen to the people because of their words, according to Jeremiah 5:14?
options: God will make His words in their mouth fire to devour the people
They will be given peace and prosperity
They will be forgiven their sins
questions.correctAnswer: God will make His words in their mouth fire to devour the people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:14 states that because of their words, God will make His words in their mouth fire, and the people will be like wood consumed by fire.

questions.question: From where will the nation come that God will bring against Israel, according to Jeremiah 5:15?
questions.correctAnswer: From far
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:15 says God will bring a nation upon Israel from far away, a mighty and ancient nation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 5:21: 'Hear now this, O ______ people, and without understanding.'
questions.correctAnswer: foolish
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:21 directly calls the people foolish and without understanding.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 5:22 says that the waves of the sea can prevail over the sand God has placed as a boundary.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:22 states the waves toss themselves but cannot prevail over the sand placed by God's decree.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:25, what have the people's iniquities and sins caused?
options: They have turned away good things and withheld blessings
They have brought peace to the land
They have strengthened the city walls
questions.correctAnswer: They have turned away good things and withheld blessings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:25 explains that the people's sins have turned away good things and withheld blessings from them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 5:27 compares the houses of wicked men to a cage full of birds.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:27 uses the simile of a cage full of birds to describe houses full of deceit.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:28, what have the wicked men failed to do?
options: Judge the cause of the fatherless and the needy
questions.correctAnswer: Judge the cause of the fatherless and the needy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:28 says the wicked men do not judge the cause of the fatherless or defend the rights of the needy.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 5:31 states that the people love the false prophecies and the priests' rule by them.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:31 says the people love to have false prophecy and the priests' rule by it.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 5 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 5:1 teach us about the importance of seeking truth and justice in daily life?
options: We should look diligently for those who execute judgment and seek truth
We should ignore the injustices around us
Only leaders are responsible for justice
Truth is relative and can be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: We should look diligently for those who execute judgment and seek truth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:1 encourages us to actively seek out people who practice justice and seek truth, which underlines the biblical virtue of integrity and fairness in daily life. This is supported by verses 5:1-3 which emphasize God's displeasure when truth is lacking.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with maintaining honesty at work. Based on Jeremiah 5, what biblical truth can you share about integrity?
options: God values truth and punishes deceit
It is acceptable to lie if it benefits you
Dishonesty is rewarded in the end
questions.correctAnswer: God values truth and punishes deceit
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:2-3 shows that swearing falsely is condemned by God, and He watches over truth. Integrity is vital for faithful living as seen in verses 5:2-3 and 5:29 where God promises to avenge deceit and injustice.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 5:4-5 teach us about humility and recognizing our need for God's guidance?
options: Those who know not the way of the LORD are foolish
Self-reliance is better than seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Those who know not the way of the LORD are foolish
questions.explanation: Verses 5:4-5 highlight that knowing God's ways and judgment is wisdom, and ignoring this is foolishness. This teaches humility, acknowledging our need for God's guidance and correction.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 5:6 describe the consequences of disobedience and backsliding, and what practical lesson does it teach?
options: Disobedience leads to destruction by enemies
Only physical enemies are a threat
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to destruction by enemies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:6 uses imagery of lions, wolves, and leopards to illustrate how disobedience and backsliding bring devastating consequences. It reminds believers to persevere in obedience to avoid ruin.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 5:7-8, what biblical principle about faithfulness in family and marriage can be drawn?
options: Fidelity and faithfulness are essential, and adultery is condemned
Family and marriage are unimportant to God
Adultery is acceptable if no one is caught
questions.correctAnswer: Fidelity and faithfulness are essential, and adultery is condemned
questions.explanation: Verses 5:7-8 condemn adultery and unfaithfulness, showing God’s displeasure with those who forsake Him and break marital vows, emphasizing the importance of faithfulness in family life.

questions.question: What warning does Jeremiah 5:9 give about God's response to a nation that forsakes Him?
options: God will seek vengeance and not pardon such a nation
God will overlook their sins forever
God’s soul will be pleased with disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God will seek vengeance and not pardon such a nation
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:9 warns that God’s soul will be avenged on a nation that forsakes Him, teaching the importance of repentance and obedience to avoid His judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 5:10-11 illustrate the consequences of unfaithfulness and broken covenant with God for a community?
options: Jerusalem’s defenses will be broken because they are not the LORD’s
God will protect unfaithful people indefinitely
Broken covenant has no effect on community safety
Communities can rely solely on their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem’s defenses will be broken because they are not the LORD’s
questions.explanation: Verses 5:10-11 describe how God will allow Jerusalem’s walls and defenses to be destroyed due to Israel and Judah’s treachery, which teaches that faithfulness to God secures protection.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:12-13, what is the danger of rejecting God's word and trusting false prophets?
options: The word will become like wind, empty and ineffective
God’s word is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: The word will become like wind, empty and ineffective
questions.explanation: Verses 5:12-13 warn that rejecting God’s word and trusting false prophets results in emptiness and deception, emphasizing the need for discerning truth in spiritual leadership.

questions.question: What practical lesson about divine discipline is taught in Jeremiah 5:14-15 when God sends a foreign nation against Israel?
options: God uses nations as instruments of correction for sin
Foreign nations are always evil without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God uses nations as instruments of correction for sin
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:14-15 teaches that God may send powerful foreign nations as a form of discipline to correct His people, reminding believers of the consequences of persistent sin and rebellion.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 5:16-17 describe the effects of judgment on the community's provision and security?
options: The nation’s harvest, flocks, and cities will be devastated
Security is always guaranteed regardless of sin
questions.correctAnswer: The nation’s harvest, flocks, and cities will be devastated
questions.explanation: Verses 5:16-17 describe how judgment results in loss of food, animals, and destruction of cities, teaching that spiritual unfaithfulness affects all areas of life including provision and security.

questions.question: A fellow believer asks why God allows hardships. Based on Jeremiah 5:18-19, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Hardships come because of forsaking God and serving strangers
God ignores the sins of His people
questions.correctAnswer: Hardships come because of forsaking God and serving strangers
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:18-19 explains that hardships are consequences of forsaking God and serving foreign gods, underscoring the importance of faithfulness and repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 5:21-22 teaches that God's power over creation should cause people to fear and respect Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 5:21-22 affirm God's sovereign control over nature, such as the sea's boundaries, urging people to fear and tremble before Him as the Creator and Sustainer.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 5:23-25 describes a people with a rebellious heart who fail to fear God and whose sins cause blessings to be withheld.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 5:23-25 describe the people's rebellion and lack of reverence towards God, which leads to their iniquities turning blessings away, highlighting the link between obedience and provision.

questions.question: Complete the sentence based on Jeremiah 5:26-28: Among God's people are found wicked men who ________.
options: lay wait and set traps to catch men
care for the needy and judge fairly
honestly serve others and teach truth
questions.correctAnswer: lay wait and set traps to catch men
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:26-28 describes wicked men among the people who lay snares and traps, living deceitfully and failing to judge justly, warning against hypocrisy and injustice.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 5:29-31 warn about the consequences of false prophecy and corrupt leadership?
options: False prophets and priests mislead the people, who love it, leading to disaster
The people reject falsehood and repent quickly
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets and priests mislead the people, who love it, leading to disaster
questions.explanation: Verses 5:29-31 warn that false prophets and priests lead the people astray, who enjoy this deception, resulting in a 'wonderful and horrible thing' and pending judgment, calling for discernment and integrity in spiritual leadership.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 5.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 5:1, what is the LORD commanding to be found in the streets of Jerusalem?
options: A man that executeth judgment and seeketh the truth
A prophet to deliver a message
questions.correctAnswer: A man that executeth judgment and seeketh the truth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:1 explicitly commands to seek a man who executes judgment and seeks the truth, highlighting the absence of justice and truth in Jerusalem.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:3 uses a metaphor comparing the people's faces to what material to illustrate their stubbornness?
questions.correctAnswer: Rock
questions.explanation: The verse states their faces are harder than a rock, symbolizing their refusal to repent or accept correction.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:6, which three animals symbolize the coming judgment upon the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Lion, wolf, leopard
questions.explanation: Verse 6 uses these predators as metaphors for invading forces that will destroy the cities due to many transgressions.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 5:7 accuse the children of doing after being fed to the full by the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaking God and committing adultery
questions.explanation: The verse depicts the children as forsaking God and assembling in harlots' houses, indicating spiritual adultery and idolatry.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:10 instructs to destroy the walls but not make a full end. What is the reason given for this partial destruction?
options: Because the battlements are not the LORD's
questions.correctAnswer: Because the battlements are not the LORD's
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states the battlements are not the LORD's, thus full destruction is withheld as a form of judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 5:12 describe the people's attitude toward the LORD's judgment?
options: They deny that evil will come upon them
They fervently repent and seek forgiveness
They prepare for the coming famine
They build altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They deny that evil will come upon them
questions.explanation: The people falsely claim that the LORD is not responsible and that no evil, sword, or famine will come upon them.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:14 uses the imagery of 'fire' and 'wood' to describe what divine action?
options: God making His words fire in the prophet's mouth and the people as wood to be devoured
God creating a protective fire around Jerusalem
God lighting a fire for sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God making His words fire in the prophet's mouth and the people as wood to be devoured
questions.explanation: This metaphor illustrates God's judgment where His prophetic words become consuming fire and the people are like wood consumed by it.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:15 foretells the coming of a nation described as all of the following EXCEPT:
options: A nation whose language is understood
questions.correctAnswer: A nation whose language is understood
questions.explanation: The verse says the nation is mighty and ancient, from afar, and whose language they do not understand, so 'understood' is incorrect.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:17, what will this invading nation consume?
options: Harvest, bread, flocks, herds, vines, and fig trees
Only the vineyards and olive groves
questions.correctAnswer: Harvest, bread, flocks, herds, vines, and fig trees
questions.explanation: Verse 17 lists all these resources as being consumed, indicating comprehensive devastation of the land.

questions.question: True or False: In Jeremiah 5:18, the LORD declares He will completely destroy the people without any mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:18 states the LORD will not make a full end with them, showing an element of mercy and preservation.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:22 uses the imagery of natural boundaries to illustrate what attribute of God?
options: His inability to stop the sea
His wrath against the sea creatures
questions.correctAnswer: His sovereign control over creation
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God setting boundaries for the sea that cannot be crossed, symbolizing His ultimate authority.

questions.question: Which characteristic is NOT attributed to the people in Jeremiah 5:23-24?
options: Fear and reverence for the LORD
Failure to acknowledge God’s provision of rain
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and reverence for the LORD
questions.explanation: These verses criticize the people for their rebellion and lack of fear of God, not for reverence.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 5:26-27, what are the wicked men compared to?
questions.correctAnswer: A cage full of birds
questions.explanation: Their houses full of deceit are likened to cages full of birds, illustrating entrapment and wickedness.

questions.question: What social injustice is highlighted in Jeremiah 5:28 as being overlooked by the wicked?
options: Judging the cause of the fatherless and needy
questions.correctAnswer: Judging the cause of the fatherless and needy
questions.explanation: The verse condemns their failure to judge righteously for the vulnerable despite their prosperity.

questions.question: Jeremiah 5:31 declares the people love falsehoods prophesied by whom?
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets and priests
questions.explanation: The verse states the prophets prophesy falsely and the priests bear rule by their means, which the people prefer.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 5 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 5 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the criterion God asks Jeremiah to search for in Jerusalem to pardon the city?
options: A man who executeth judgment and seeketh the truth
A prophet who can predict the future
questions.correctAnswer: A man who executeth judgment and seeketh the truth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:1 calls for finding a man who practices true justice and seeks truth, reflecting the biblical emphasis on righteousness as foundational for pardon. Similarly, Proverbs 21:3 stresses justice and righteousness as God's delight; Micah 6:8 calls for justice, mercy, and humility; Isaiah 1:17 commands seeking justice; and Zechariah 7:9 also calls for justice and mercy.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe those who say 'The LORD liveth'?
questions.correctAnswer: They swear falsely
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:2 reveals hypocrisy where people affirm God's life but swear falsely, illustrating the disconnect between profession and practice. This theme reoccurs in Psalm 78:36-37 where they spoke falsely about God; in Isaiah 29:13, people honor God with lips but hearts are far; in Matthew 15:8 Jesus quotes this hypocrisy; and in 1 John 4:20, profession without love is falsehood.

questions.question: What is the people's response to God's correction as described in Jeremiah 5:3?
options: They have made their faces harder than a rock and refused to return
They humbly repent and seek forgiveness
They flee to God for mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They have made their faces harder than a rock and refused to return
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:3 depicts their stubbornness and refusal to respond to God's discipline, echoing hardness of heart seen in Ezekiel 3:7, Pharaoh's refusal in Exodus 7:13, Israel’s rebellion in Hebrews 3:8, and Jesus’ warning about hardened hearts in Mark 6:52.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:4, why are the people considered foolish?
options: Because they do not know the way of the LORD nor the judgment of their God
Because they reject the prophets’ words
Because they oppose the king’s authority
questions.correctAnswer: Because they do not know the way of the LORD nor the judgment of their God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:4 highlights ignorance of God's ways as folly, consistent with Psalm 14:1 stating fools say there is no God, Hosea 4:6 on lack of knowledge causing destruction, Proverbs 1:7 emphasizing fear of the LORD as knowledge's beginning, and Romans 1:21 showing that rejecting God’s knowledge leads to foolishness.

questions.question: What punishment does God declare will come upon the people for their transgressions in Jeremiah 5:6?
options: A lion, a wolf, and a leopard will destroy them
A flood will sweep over the land
A famine will afflict the nation
questions.correctAnswer: A lion, a wolf, and a leopard will destroy them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:6 uses metaphorical predators to describe coming judgment, symbolizing violent destruction as in Hosea 13:7, Nahum 2:12’s lion imagery, Ezekiel 22:25’s wolves and lions representing enemies, and Revelation 13:2 where beasts symbolize destructive powers.

questions.question: What is the nature of the adultery committed by the children of Israel according to Jeremiah 5:7?
options: They forsook God and swore by false gods, assembling in harlots' houses
They worshipped the LORD but also Baal
They broke the covenant with the priests
questions.correctAnswer: They forsook God and swore by false gods, assembling in harlots' houses
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:7 describes spiritual adultery as idolatry and immoral assemblies, paralleling Hosea 4:12 on harlotry as idolatry, Ezekiel 16:32 on adulterous Israel, James 4:4 warning against friendship with the world as adultery against God, and Revelation 2:20 condemning participation in false practices.

questions.question: What reason does God give for not making a full end with Israel according to Jeremiah 5:18?
options: He will not completely destroy them despite their sin
He has chosen to completely forgive them without punishment
He plans to send a Messiah immediately
They repent sincerely and turn back to Him
questions.correctAnswer: He will not completely destroy them despite their sin
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:18 shows God's mercy in withholding complete destruction, reflecting His covenant faithfulness as in Genesis 9:11, Psalm 89:34 on not violating covenant, Lamentations 3:22-23 on steadfast love, and Romans 11:26 emphasizing partial hardening for eventual salvation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the nation God will bring upon Israel as described in Jeremiah 5:15?
options: It is a mighty, ancient nation with an unfamiliar language
It is a small, weak nation that will be easily defeated
It is a neighboring tribe that will be assimilated
It is a nation of priests who will convert Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It is a mighty, ancient nation with an unfamiliar language
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:15 foretells a powerful foreign nation as an instrument of judgment, echoing Assyria's role in Isaiah 10:5, Babylon's dominance in Daniel 2:38, the Gentile nations in Acts 13:47, and the eschatological judgment in Revelation 19:15.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 5:22, what natural phenomenon does God use to illustrate His power and authority?
options: The bound of the sea that it cannot pass
The rising and setting of the sun
questions.correctAnswer: The bound of the sea that it cannot pass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:22 uses the sea's boundary to show God's sovereign control over creation, paralleling Job 38:11 where God sets the sea's limit, Psalm 104:9 on the sea not passing bounds, Isaiah 50:2 showing God's control, and Hebrews 1:3 affirming Christ's sustaining power over all things.

questions.question: What heart condition does Jeremiah accuse the people of having in Jeremiah 5:23?
questions.correctAnswer: A revolting and rebellious heart
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:23 describes the people's heart as rebellious, consistent with Deuteronomy 9:7 on stiff-necked hearts, Ezekiel 36:26 promising new hearts, Romans 8:7 on the mind set against God, and Hebrews 3:8 warning against hardening hearts.

questions.question: What is withheld from the people because of their sins according to Jeremiah 5:25?
options: The presence of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Good things and blessings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:25 links iniquity with withholding blessings, corresponding to Malachi 3:9-10 about withholding tithes and blessings, Psalm 85:12 on righteousness bringing peace, Isaiah 59:2 separating from God by sin, and James 1:17 confirming all good gifts come from God.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe the wicked men among the people in Jeremiah 5:26?
options: They lay snares and traps to catch men
They build altars to the true God
They care for the fatherless and needy
questions.correctAnswer: They lay snares and traps to catch men
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:26 portrays wicked men as deceptive predators, echoing Psalm 7:15 on trap setting, Proverbs 1:10 on enticement to evil, Matthew 16:23 where Jesus calls Satan a tempter, and 2 Timothy 3:13 warning of evil men and seducers.

questions.question: What is the condition of the houses of the wicked as described in Jeremiah 5:27?
options: Full of deceit like a cage full of birds
Filled with the Spirit of God
questions.correctAnswer: Full of deceit like a cage full of birds
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:27 uses imagery of deceitful houses full of trapped victims, reflecting Proverbs 11:3 on integrity guarding the innocent, Psalm 52:2 on deceitful tongues, Ezekiel 22:27 on houses full of violence, and Colossians 3:9 prohibiting lying among believers.

questions.question: What failure in judgment does Jeremiah highlight about the leaders in Jeremiah 5:28?
options: They do not judge the cause of the fatherless or the needy
They judge fairly and defend the weak
They repent and turn from evil
questions.correctAnswer: They do not judge the cause of the fatherless or the needy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:28 condemns leaders ignoring justice for vulnerable people, consistent with Psalm 82:3-4 calling for defense of the weak, Isaiah 1:17 urging justice for orphans, James 1:27 defining true religion as caring for orphans and widows, and Proverbs 31:8-9 commanding speaking up for the destitute.

questions.question: What is the consequence God declares for the false prophets and priests in Jeremiah 5:31?
options: They prophesy falsely and lead people astray, and God questions their end
They are rewarded with great honor
They are ignored by the people
questions.correctAnswer: They prophesy falsely and lead people astray, and God questions their end
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 5:31 warns against false prophecy and priestly corruption, echoing Ezekiel 13:3 condemning false prophets, Matthew 7:15 warning of false prophets, 2 Peter 2:1 on destructive heresies, and Revelation 19:20 on false prophets being judged.
